title: Tiger Woods Has a Very Bad Day at the British Open
abstract: The three-time Open champion, including two on the Old Course at St. Andrews, was six over par after the first round that started with a double bogey on the first hole.

multimedia.caption: “Looks like I’m going to have to shoot 66 tomorrow to have a chance,” Woods said.
“Looks like I’m going to have to shoot 66 tomorrow to have a chance,” Woods said.
“Looks like I’m going to have to shoot 66 tomorrow to have a chance,” Woods said.

title: In M.L.B.’s Labor Talks, Latino Voices Are Few and Far Between
abstract: A deadline looms on an international draft, but players from Latin America, who would be affected more than anyone, are largely absent from union leadership.

multimedia.caption: Francisco Lindor of the Mets, right, was one of only two Latino players on the executive board born outside the mainland United States when the players’ union was negotiating its new collective bargaining agreement with Major League Baseball.
multimedia.copyright: Greg Lovett/The Palm Beach Post, via Associated Press

title: The Impossible Task of Keeping Up With the Ingebrigtsens
abstract: The Kardashians of Norway are middle-distance runners who have competed on the global stage. But it’s Jakob, 21, who transformed from onetime prodigy to generational talent.

title: Pogacar Attacks Tour Leader on Iconic Climb, to No Avail
abstract: The picturesque switchbacks and enthusiastic crowds on the ride to Alpe d’Huez make it the most famous climb in cycling.

title: Science and Data Change Soccer’s Definition of Old
abstract: Top clubs have long looked to shed players once they hit age 30. But those presumptions rely on outdated logic, statistics show.

multimedia.caption: Barcelona may be close to a deal for striker Robert Lewandowski, who turns 34 in August.
Barcelona may be close to a deal for striker Robert Lewandowski, who turns 34 in August.
Barcelona may be close to a deal for striker Robert Lewandowski, who turns 34 in August.

title: W.N.B.A. Adds Charter Flights for the Finals. Here Is Why That Matters.
abstract: Teams usually fly on commercial airlines, but that will change for the W.N.B.A. finals. This could be good news for players’ health, finances and game.

multimedia.caption: W.N.B.A. Commissioner Cathy Engelbert said the league would permit charter travel for teams during the finals.
W.N.B.A. Commissioner Cathy Engelbert said the league would permit charter travel for teams during the finals.

title: How Mo Farah Outran His Sad Beginnings
abstract: The distance runner, who said this week that he was trafficked to the United Kingdom as a child, trained under Alberto Salazar on his way to becoming a four-time Olympic gold medalist.

multimedia.caption: Mo Farah, celebrating a victory at a Diamond League event in Brussels in 2020, revealed this week that he was trafficked to the United Kingdom as a child under a false name.

title: Beauty of the Old Course Upstages LIV Golf Angst, for Now
abstract: Seven years is an unusually long gap, but the R&A, which runs the British Open, delayed a return to St. Andrews to ensure that it could host the tournament’s 150th edition, which begins Thursday.

multimedia.caption: Originally scheduled for 2021, the St. Andrews celebration got pushed back a year because of the pandemic-induced cancellation in 2020.

title: Bad Planning and Errors, Not Fans, Led to Champions League Chaos, Report Says
abstract: A French Senate inquiry faulted the authorities for blaming large crowds of supporters instead of owning up to their failures, after violence and confusion marred a final near Paris.

multimedia.caption: Many Liverpool fans were unable to enter the Stade de France in time for the scheduled kickoff of the Champions League final in May, prompting officials to delay the start of the match.

title: N.F.L. Players Pay a Small Price When Accused of Violence Against Women
abstract: A peer-reviewed study found that players who are arrested in these cases generally do not suffer major career consequences.

title: It Really Wasn’t Cricket: The Strange Case of the Fake Indian Premier League
abstract: The bats and balls were real, but not much else was authentic in what officials said was an elaborate scheme to dupe Russian gamblers through hoax games streamed on YouTube.

title: What are the Maccabiah Games?
abstract: Israel’s biggest sporting event, which President Biden is scheduled to attend on Thursday evening, is often referred to as the Jewish Olympics.

title: Twist on the Mountain: Vingegaard Grabs Tour de France Lead
abstract: A daring attack near the end of a punishing stage put a Danish rider in the yellow jersey, left Tadej Pogacar in his wake and upended the standings.

title: Some Classic Golf Courses Have Fallen Off the Open Schedule
abstract: Clubs that were the foundation of this tournament no longer host. They are considered too small, too remote or too Trump.

title: To Win the British Open, You Have to Go Through the Road Hole
abstract: Some say the 17th hole on the Old Course at St. Andrews is the hardest in the world. Many championship dreams have died there.

multimedia.caption: Tom Watson, the defending champion, facing down the 17th hole, known as the Road Hole, on the Old Course at St. Andrews in the 1984 British Open. Watson was tied with Seve Ballesteros coming into the notoriously difficult hole.

title: Two Chances, Two Goals and Two Wins for Germany
abstract: Spain had more of the ball and did more with it. But Germany, the standard of excellence at the Euros, did enough to reach the quarterfinals.

title: Mo Farah’s Revelations Put Spotlight on U.K.’s Hard-line Policy
abstract: Experts hope the running star’s revelations will humanize migrants’ struggles, but they don’t expect policy changes in a country that is trying to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda.

title: Tiger Woods Has Harsh Words for LIV Golf and Greg Norman
abstract: Two days before the British Open starts at golf’s oldest course, the 15-time major champion said he worried about young players defecting to the Saudi-backed golf series.

multimedia.caption: “What these players are doing for guaranteed money, what is the incentive to practice?” Tiger Woods asked.

title: Inside Brazil’s 40-Year Rise to Global Surfing Dominance
abstract: This generation of Brazilian surfers is so dominant, so undeniable, that it has earned a nickname: the Brazilian Storm.
